column2: 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient)

column2: disease control, 35-44 Male  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: I take 3000 mg keppra 2x daily as well as 200 mg lamictol 2x daily.  This combination controls my convulsive seizure activity but not my sps activity.  I still have deja vu, memory, and vision issues.  Unfortunately, the convulsive seizure activity is controlled so well that I mentally don't take my meds because I am "cured".  I then will have a grand maul seizure after missing a couple days of meds.  This med combination has worked very well for me and once I convince myself I will never be "cured" of my epileptic activity I should be limited to mental attributes as opposed to physical attributes.

column2: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient)
column9: I started taking keppra and had to switch to xr still having some breakthru once every few months going to be adding lamictal xr after reading the reviews a little scared to add that drug does not seem to help with control. will be slowly increasing the dose hoping that the side effects are small. I take 3000mg of xr and will be taking 200 mg of the lamictal xr. Does anyone else take this combo and give me feedback on this. I do notice the side effects with keppra emotional more then anything. any info would help me out. THANKS!

column2: adoug, 25-34 Male  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I began taking this drug because of frequent sps which were exhibited through deja vu/false memories followed by severe jamais vu.  My seizures never generalized. The only complaint I have is that now I have strange dreams that are quite vivid. They are not frightening, just strange.

column2: 55-64 Male  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: I take KeppraXR 1000mg once daily (at night)with Trileptal twice daily for COMPLEX Partial seizures (epilepsy).  I also have Vegus Nerve Stimulator (VNS)implanted. My neurologist has me continue with Keppra until and if newer med comes available.

column2: 45-54 Male  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
Natalie, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient)
column9: I was initially diagnosed with post traumatic epilepsy two years ago and was suffering from almost daily seizures.  I was put on a relatively high dose of Keppra and the side effects initially were horrifying.  I was borderline suicidal, severely depressed, aggressive and violent towards my husband - the complete opposite to the kind of person I really am.  In hindsight I should have been taken off the medication but the doctor simply said it was a side effect.  Now, two years later I realise that whilst for some people the side effects can be unbearable (usually just in the beggining)the drug actually works and I would not come off it now.  However, do not withdraw from this medication without medical supervision or advice.  I came off it because the side effects were unbearable but didn't tell anyone and ended up in status epilepticus, ventilated for 7 days in ICU.  Dangerous.  But the drug has generally less side effects than drugs such as topamax (I couldn't talk, walk, speak or write sometimes on this drug and couldn't make even simple decisions).
